projectPurpose: To provide a secure, modern, and memory-safe implementation of the TLS (Transport Layer Security) protocol as a library for applications written in Rust.
mainFeatures: Focuses on cryptographic security with minimal configuration
Avoids unsafe features and obsolete cryptography by default
Pure Rust implementation for memory safety
Supports ECDSA, Ed25519, or RSA authentication
Provides encrypted pipes; does not handle network I/O

alternatives.name: OpenSSL
alternatives.license: Open Source (OpenSSL License and SSLeay License)
mainFeatures: Supports a wide range of protocols (including older versions)
Extensive feature set for certificate and key management

alternatives.name: BoringSSL
platforms: Primarily used in Chromium, Android, Google services
mainFeatures: Fork of OpenSSL with focus on smaller codebase and safer API
Removes support for some older/weak features

alternatives.name: wolfSSL
mainFeatures: Lightweight and optimized for resource-constrained environments
Small footprint and low memory usage

alternatives.name: GnuTLS
mainFeatures: Provides C API and bindings for other languages

alternatives.name: mbed TLS
mainFeatures: Small code size and memory footprint

alternatives.name: LibreSSL
mainFeatures: Fork of OpenSSL with focus on code cleanup and security
Aims for a more modern codebase

alternatives.name: System-native TLS
mainFeatures: Updates handled by the OS vendor

marketPositioning: Rustls is positioned as a secure, modern, and memory-safe alternative to traditional TLS libraries, written in Rust. It differentiates itself by explicitly avoiding legacy and unsafe features, focusing on modern TLS standards (1.2 and 1.3), and leveraging Rust's safety guarantees. It appeals to developers in the Rust ecosystem and those prioritizing enhanced security and performance, offering competitive speed and lower memory usage compared to widely used C/C++ alternatives like OpenSSL.
